In this unit we are continuing to explore rational numbers, including operations and their properties with positive, negative numbers and zero and how to recognize and use these operations to solve problems. At the end of this Investigation,

What do you know about rational numbers and their operations?

Student reflections should include algorithms for multiplying and dividing positive and negative rational numbers.

Student should have an algorithm for multiplying any two rational numbers, connecting to context, number lines, and/or patterns (multiplication of one factor by series of consecutive numbers).

  • When the numbers are either both positive or both negative—multiply the numbers and the sign of the product is positive.
  • When one factor is positive and one factor is negative—multiply the numbers and the sign of the product is negative.

Student should have an algorithm for dividing any two rational numbers, connecting to context, number lines, and/or patterns (fact families).

  • When the numbers are either both positive or both negative—divide the numbers and the sign of the quotient is positive.
  • When one factor is positive and one factor is negative—divide the numbers and the sign of the quotient is negative.

Student reflections should include some properties of numbers, such as:

  • If you multiply a number by its multiplicative inverse, the product is 1. So (a/b)*(b/a)=1.
  • One is the multiplicative identity for rational numbers. So, a * 1 = a.
  • Multiplication of rational numbers is Commutative. p * q = q * p
  • Division of rational numbers is not Commutative. p ÷ q ≠ q ÷ p

Reflections on the Mathematical Practices

As we worked on the Problems in this Investigation, we used prior mathematical knowledge to make sense of them. We also applied Mathematical Practices to solve the Problems. For example,

Hector explained his reasoning for Problem 3.2 in the following way:

Jake and I knew that a negative number times a negative number is positive. This helped us predict the sign of the product of a set of numbers. If there is an even number of numbers that are negative, we can group these numbers in pairs. The product of each pair is positive. Then we are left with positive numbers, so the final product is positive.

If there are an uneven number of negative numbers, the product is negative because there will always be a negative number that is not paired with another negative number. And a negative times a positive is negative. You can also write addition equations as subtraction problems. These patterns enabled us to rewrite equations to make it easier to find the missing number and complete the equation.
